Posts.Content: Mar 5, 2014 05:23AM Jill49 wrote: Thanks for sharing your questions, Brenda.   I definitely don't want to spend my last weeks or months feeling awful on chemo or having unnecessary tests, but I, too, wonder how I will know when enough is enough. At this point when my onc talks about balancing quality of life with treatment of disease,  I am clear that I am willing put up with the drug se's I've had so far to stay alive.  And I have been for over 5 years with mets.  Not always easy ones, as you all know, but for now my life is still worth living. Ah, a peaceful, comfortable, dignified death.  I believe it's possible, especially if I make it clear what I want and don't want (are docs ordering more drugs and tests to avoid malpractice suits?).  I continue to work with my mind so I won't spend my last days or months struggling, confused or in a panic.  A mind of equanimity, a room with a view, as little pain as possible, and supported by those I love.  Am I aiming too high?  ;-) For now, I am on a mission to help my family in advance by cleaning out closets and getting rid of accumulated stuff we don't use.

I wish you many years and much joy. In the meantime I send you hugs and warm thoughts.

Posts.Content: Feb 19, 2013 07:25PM Jill49 wrote: Ebru, there is a quote by Bob Marley that says you don't know how strong you really are until you have no choice.  Sometimes we do learn the important things when we are faced with the biggest challenges. oh how I would like to say I get it, now can we rewind and delete this chapter. I would love to come to Turkey.  I was in Istanbul and Izmir last May and loved it! I saw all the important sights, but especially loved simple things like having tea in a cafe that specialized in Turkish Delight (Hafiz Mustafa), shopping in the Grand Bazaar, wandering about and talking with people. A cruise up the Bosphorus was beautiful and visiting Ephesus and Pergamon was spectacular. Makes me smile just to think about it!
Posts.Title: Just think positive... BouncingBetties PinkShirtNow

Posts.Content: Feb 19, 2013 05:39AM Jill49 wrote: In most cases people who say the things we hate are, as someone quoted, trying to make themselves feel better. I understand that and rarely respond to statements like you look great, you've such a great attitude, with anything other than a weak thank you.  I am not a fighter or one to suppress my feelings. I follow the guidance of my doctors and hope for the best and prepare myself for the worst. When I think of dying from this disease I do not feel like a loser, nor do I think that I am the cause of my demise because I feel scared or depressed from time to time. I do believe that true bravery doesn't try to crush emotions.  I still have a body and breath and do my best to be fully present in my life, one day at a time, with appreciation and gratitude for what brings me joy and pleasure, and allowing space for the more difficult emotions to arise and dissolve. Caryn, I am also not Christian, but have never had anyone who is tell me I just need to accept Jesus and all will be well or that if I don't I am lost. How disrespectful and cruel!  Such a judgement would leave me speechless, if not unleash a sharp response.
Posts.Title: Just think positive... BouncingBetties PinkShirtNow

Posts.Content: Feb 19, 2013 05:53PM Jill49 wrote: BouncingBetties - I recoil at the term good death as it sometimes, in my mind, implies a competition - who can do it better. If I don't do it well, somehow I've screwed up. At the same time, I sometimes imagine dying - usually in the middle of the night, lying in bed awake, and neither feel morbid nor particularly scared.  At those time a good death means to me being surrounded by people I love, accepting the journey I am about to take, and feeling some sense of gentleness and peace. And no pain! The saddest part of it all is leaving behind people who will feel the loss. In the meantime, I aim to live a good life as Soleil505 said. I'm in no hurry to be evicted from this body anytime soon.
Posts.Title: Just think positive... BouncingBetties PinkShirtNow

Posts.Content: May 8, 2014 03:49AM Jill49 wrote: Just completing wbr and maybe beginning abraxane. Got a transition haircut yesterday.  In the 18 years since my life with bc began, I have never completely lost my hair.  Back in 1996 it thinned a lot, but I didn't need a wig. I remember the tears as clumps of hair came away from my head in the shower, feeling so vulnerable, so out of control.   I'm more emotionally ready this time and some of that is thanks to you all for sharing yourselves so honestly, kindly, and with such great humor.  My darling hairdresser gave me his cell phone # so I can call him as soon as the hair starts leaving my head and he will take care of the rest of it right away.   BTW, have you seen the documentary call Mondays at Racine (HBO) about two sisters who open their hair salon every 3rd Monday to help women who are losing their hair to cancer treatment?  I cried from beginning to end - beautifully done.
Posts.Title: MBC Head trends 2014 spring/summer ;) stagefree stagefree

Posts.Content: May 5, 2014 09:33AM Jill49 wrote: Ebru - thank you for starting this thread.  I am about to lose my hair completely for the first time and seeing all you beauties is helping me so much. I'm getting my hairdresser to give me a Judi Dench cut this week (kind of like yours Ebru) so I can transition without clumps of hair coming away from my head at once. That happened 18 years ago when my hair thinned, but didn't completely disappear. So creepy. Anyway, you're all beautiful, bold, sassy and altogether awesome!  Thank you for showing yourselves with such confidence.
Posts.Title: MBC Head trends 2014 spring/summer ;) stagefree stagefree

Posts.Content: Jan 15, 2013 12:33AM Jill49 wrote: Hello everyone, I'm a 63 year old mother of two amazing sons (31 and 36), grandmother to a 7 month old beautiful girl, and wife to a wonderful husband of 37 years.  I have bone and lung mets and have been stable on Xeloda for over two years.  I was treated for stage IIB in 1996 and was NED for 12 years.  Been stage IV for 4.5 years and doing well so far under the circumstances. I am an American living in Nova Scotia, Canada and work full time for a Buddhist meditation organization, supporting volunteers in over 100 centres worldwide. I've been studying Japanese tea ceremony for over 10 years and find it is the one activity that allows me to be fully in the present and not have one thought about cancer - a profoundly serene place of beauty and grace. I love to travel and for the past few years have shed my naturally cautious with money nature and said "lets go there" several times. The list of places I dream about visiting is long and I hope I still have enough stamina and stability to go to at least some of them. I thought for a while that I had made peace with this monster, but now that I have a granddaughter, I am so not ready for the lights to go out.  I long to see her walk and talk, play with her, hug and kiss her... I am heartbroken to read posts from so many very young women with small children. I wish you all many years, many smiles, many hugs and all the support you need to navigate your way along this bumpy road.
Posts.Title: Roll Call 2013 LilSchatzie reader123

Posts.Content: Aug 12, 2013 10:07AM Jill49 wrote: So many bits and pieces are being taken away from us by disease, treatments, surgeries.  Is it any surprise that we have down days. I've been told by my radiation oncologist that tears remove toxins from our body that accumulate from stress, so cry a river. (they also kill bacteria and lubricate our eyes among other things) Thinking of you, Leah. I hope that the cloud passes quickly and that the coming days are brighter.

Posts.Title: "Help Me" redwolf8812 Iwillwinthisbattle

Posts.Content: Mar 7, 2013 11:24AM Jill49 wrote: I was stage IIB and 12 years later Stage IV (how my onc refers to it) or IIB with mets. What's the difference really - the outcome doesn't change. I agree that calling breast cancer that has spread either bone cancer, liver cancer, lung or brain cancer is a bit annoying.  But I have to admit that before I started traveling the cancer road, I knew very little. I don't talk much about this with people not dealing with cancer.  People, in general, want to feel like things are ok and many shy away from harsh realities. Thank you all for your support and understanding, though I wish none of us have to be going through this. I am also baffled why anyone with any critical illness wouldn't want to know something about their situation.  My onc engages me in the decisions about my treatments either based upon managing side effects, or what treatment should come next.  He will give me options and reasons why one or another would make sense. I would find it very difficult to be in the dark about what is happening, what choices I have, what to expect, etc.

Posts.Content: Mar 7, 2013 06:37AM Jill49 wrote: These sad passings have touched all of us.  I, if I'm still here, will certainly be one of those who responds to your DH with your link.  What a lovely thought. And a great song - I never heard that one. Strange, but a few days ago, nursing a cold, lying on the sofa covered in blankets to ease the chills, my mind drifting here and there, I found myself composing a letter to my loved ones.  No last words of wisdom, but words to let them know how much I love them and that my love will always be a part of them. When the time comes, I want my DH to throw a party on my behalf for family and friends to celebrate my life and to celebrate each other.  There's no time like the present (how well we know that!) to let those you care about know how much you care about them. I hope Femara is good to you for a long long time.

Comfort in, dump out. So well said, and so obvious, really.

Posts.Content: May 10, 2013 04:03AM Jill49 wrote: Barb - I am 64, was diagnosed Stage IV in 2008 with bone and lung mets after 12 years from first DX. I am going on 5 years and still have few, if any, symptoms from the cancer, only SEs from the drugs. I've been on aromatase inhibitors (femara for a year and a half and aromasin)  I've been on Xeloda for 3 years with good results! I've been able to carry on with living and like Debbie and Glenna and find joy in so many things I took for granted before.  I still work, travel, play and laugh. There are times I feel scared, disappointed, sorry for myself and everyone else who is suffering, but I still have a life to live and refuse to let these feelings take over.  I have so much to be grateful for and try to celebrate every moment. Wishing you and everyone else here all the best.  Warm thoughts and lots of hugs.

Posts.Title: Expected Life SPAMgirl jocanuck1951

Posts.Content: Mar 11, 2014 11:30AM Jill49 wrote: I am on A/A now, since last July.  Few side effects, but I have a very itchy scalp.  Also, brittle, splitting fingernails, which I can keep under control by having them very short and polished with Hard as Nails. I was on Xeloda and stable for 3 years!!!  It was relatively easy - no nausea or other digestive upsets.  I did, like kebab, have hand foot syndrome that increased over the 3 year period.  Not surprising as I'm sure the effect of the drug is cumulative.  There were some days I found walking painful and my hands were dry and peeling.  I had only a couple of pairs of shoes that worked for me.  I did take a couple of breaks for vacation during which things healed nicely and the 7 days off in each cycle helped as well. All in all it was a small price to pay for staying stable for so long.  Hoping it works as well for you.
Posts.Title: Confused and scared stellaratovsky GatorGal

Posts.Content: Oct 16, 2012 03:50AM Jill49 wrote: Thank you for posting your comments, CoolBreeze.  We are every newly diagnosed breast cancer patient's worst nightmare. My surgeon in 1996 said that after five years I could put it in the back of my mind, at 10 years I could relax, and at twenty years, I could celebrate. I was "cured" for almost 12 years and became more and more complacent about being cancer free. Then 2008 brought the devasting news of a stage 4 DX. My attitude is positive and always has been.  Her comments are based on hope and fear, not reality. People are being told a fairy tale about this horrid disease. Jill

Posts.Content: Dec 7, 2012 02:59PM Jill49 wrote: I've been on Xgeva for at least 8 months and have not noticed any side effects.  Both Pamidronate and Zometa caused me muscle aches, but this drug has been easy and much less time consuming than a trip to the hospital for an IV delivery. I had a root canal done last month and skipped a dose so that I was off the drug for at least a month before the dental work.  No problems. I do take vitamin D and calcium.
Posts.Title: Xgeva fear LizLemon raro

Posts.Content: Mar 5, 2014 05:46PM - edited Mar 5, 2014 05:47PM by Jill49 I don't know what drugs your mom is on, but I can tell you that after 5.5 years of being treated for mets, the fatigue from drugs is sometimes overwhelming. And I wasn't nearly as active as your mom seems to have been. That change alone would be enough to cause distress.  Also, I have had bone and joint pain from both anti-hormonal drugs and bone strengtheners.  Usually ibuprofen or Tylenol helps with that. I was "cured", I thought, until mets showed up 12 years after my first diagnosis.  The good news is that I am still doing well after 5.5 years, with mets in my bones and lungs.  Sometimes I have trouble sleeping either because I have muscle aches or feel unsettled.  At those times I take a sleeping pill to help me get to sleep and stay asleep.  I do find that if I am well rested, I feel better in general - mind and body. I think it's a great idea for you to accompany your mom on one of her visits with her doctor.  I never go alone because I can't always take it all in or remember what I wanted to ask.  I have a notebook that my husband has nearly filled up with his notes from these visits.

Posts.Content: Feb 14, 2013 11:46AM Jill49 wrote: I am neither secretive or a broadcaster.  I have told my close friends and some of the people I work with, but don't talk about it, generally.  I answer questions honestly, but at the same time I don't want to be defined by cancer and have that be the first thing people think of when they're with me. I agree with texasrose - while you may be uncomfortable with having everyone know, it would, perhaps, be good for your son to know he can share with his closest friends and get the support he needs. And at the same time respect your wish for privacy. If I am doing ok, then he can say I'm doing ok. I have no idea whether my sons have shared my situation with anyone, but I leave it up to them.

Right now I have so much I want to live for from the smallest moments of joy like the songs the birds bring, to spending time with my family and friends. The dark thoughts come, but I don't follow them for long. Right now I still have a life to live. I think I will know when it's time to say no more.

Posts.Content: Mar 11, 2014 10:49AM Jill49 wrote: Brenda - I love your description of the "journey with cancer".  Gave me a good laugh. I do see my life as a journey, though.  And even though we will all end up in the same place eventually, some of us will have some pretty rough roads to travel along the way.  As Ebru once said - "life is not a five star hotel"  I love that, Ebru! Saying that, I am reminded that on a scale of 1 - 10 I couldn't possibly claim a 10 when there are so many in this world who are suffering unimaginable circumstances. The journey for me is an inner one to, hopefully, greater insight, compassion, acceptance and joy.
Posts.Title: MBC is Not a "Journey" Bestbird cliff

Posts.Content: May 9, 2013 06:48AM Jill49 wrote: How completely self-absorbed one must be to make such an unkind remark. So sorry you were the recipient of her insensitive and harsh words. Cry and rant as much as you need to to purge yourself of her poison, and then remember that she must be a very unhappy person. And don't open any more of her emails! sending you hugs and every best wish.
Posts.Title: Lets do a Sh*t People say to Metastatic BC Patients Fitztwins ChicagoGirl

Posts.Content: Jan 20, 2013 05:05PM Jill49 wrote: Oh, Sylvie. I'm sorry you are having to face this.  It is awful when you are first diagnosed with stage IV. You are not alone - this virtual community is understanding,  loving and always ready to offer support. I resisted looking at this board at first because I was having a hard time facing the reality that I was a member of this club.  Now I feel grateful that I am in the company of such caring people. I hope your current treatment makes those cancer cells cower, if not disappear.  I send every best wish for you to feel good, and enjoy many years.
Posts.Title: Saying hi... reluctantly justsylvie Annie62

Posts.Content: May 25, 2014 04:37PM Jill49 wrote: I agree that comments that minimize what we are going through are hard to take.  I am stunned at what some of you have had to hear.  It really does come down to a fear of death, I think.  Sh*t happens, life ends and for some us us the end is closer than we had expected. Horrible to turn 60?  From a psychiatrist!!!  I just turned 65, have lived with mets for nearly six years, and welcome 66, 67 and whatever age I am fortunate enough to reach.   I am now, for the first time in my life, I'm not trying to make everyone comfortable (I am more careful with my sons).  Kiwi, I love your response to the remark about the 1 in 3!  I honestly think it's helpful to gently push people a bit outside their comfort zone because death is real for all of us and it doesn't help anyone to sugar coat the words or blame the person facing it sooner than later. One of my most painful memories is how isolated and lonely I now realize my mother was when she was dying of stomach cancer.  It just wasn't something to talk openly about, maybe to keep giving the person hope (false as it was) and I'm sure she was trying to protect us from her suffering.  It still brings tears to me eyes to think about the fear and loneliness she never talked about. Thank goodness we have this forum to talk openly with people who understand. Nothing is censored here and for that I am grateful.  Thank you all for your honesty and for sharing your vulnerable hearts.
Posts.Title: Lets do a Sh*t People say to Metastatic BC Patients Fitztwins ChicagoGirl

Posts.Content: Jul 8, 2013 02:20PM Jill49 wrote: I already got hit by the bus! And yes empathy is welcome, nothing more.
Posts.Title: Lets do a Sh*t People say to Metastatic BC Patients Fitztwins ChicagoGirl

Posts.Content: Oct 25, 2013 07:23AM Jill49 wrote: I had terrible HFS, but a week off the drug certainly helped. I used gallons of lotion and cream, but found that they didn't heal. Might have prevented things from getting worse, however. I had deep grooves on the back my heels that sometimes split. Soaking my feet in a basin of cool water with epsom salts gave me relief when things were really painful. Occasionally I took a break from the drug for a cycle or two, usually if I was going on a trip or having out of town visitors. That helped a lot. The good news for me was that for 3 years Xeloda kept me stable, so I learned to put up with the discomfort. I was on a 14/7 cycle. Some people are on a 7/7. Talk to your onc about what is recommended for you and whether the 7/7 might be as effective and easier on your hands/feet. I hope you find a good balance to keep the hands and feet from feeling too bad and that the drug keeps you stable for a long time.

Posts.Title: Poll - How old were you when dx with BC Times3 Minetta57

Posts.Content: Jan 30, 2013 07:59AM Jill49 wrote: I had two children by the time I was 30 and breast fed both of them for a year - that didn't prevent me for ending up Stage IV.  I can go back over my life and think of all the choices I made, good or bad, and still not know why I am where I am. Genetically pre-disposed? Particularly sensitive to environmental toxins? Bad luck? Ebru has offered wise words - take care of yourself, cherish every moment, get a lot of sleep (with help, if necessary), breath and celebrate that you still can, shed the tears you need to shed with gentleness towards yourself, but don't get stuck there.  And as Caryn said - this is not your fault! You still have a life to live, so live it fully! There's no time like the present.  Actually there is only now.  Whether you live another 20 or 30 years or not, there is still only now. Sending warm wishes for many good years.  You will find tremendous kindness, understanding and support from this group.

Like Nel, cancer is never far from my thoughts, but it is not always front and center - I have been stage IV for over 5 years, generally feel good, and plan to be around for a while. Sending warm thoughts your way.

Posts.Content: Feb 13, 2013 06:56AM Jill49 wrote: Dear Stern,  A diagnosis like this is a shock and so hard to take, but you have many treatment options available and in time you will find a way to go on living with this new reality. I don't know which is harder - being diagnosed Stage IV from the start or soon after initial tx.  In my case I was clear for 12 years and was feeling safe and then the other shoe dropped.  HOW COULD THIS HAPPEN!  Well it did and it does. Welcome to this board where you will feel the understanding, love and support from these wondeful women. I have been stage IV for 4.5 year with mets to bones and lung.  I'm still doing well and have hopes about being around for quite a bit longer. There's a quote from Bob Marley I love - you don't know how strong you really are until being strong is the only choice you have.   Sending warm thoughts and best wishes for your treatment.

Posts.Content: Feb 15, 2013 10:29AM Jill49 wrote: So many wise words here.  Don't get caught in blaming yourself.  It's NOT your fault. We all have cancer cells in our bodies and it is unclear what causes our immune system to fail to remove them.  Could be so many things including toxic environmental exposure combined with individual vulnerability. As fitztwins said - sh*t happens. Life doesn't give us any guarantees and there is so much suffering in the world.  And joy! As others have said, you are at the beginning of this journey and will feel many difficult emotions.  And they will continue to make an appearance from time to time. We've all been there. This will change over time and you will learn to live each day fully - not so caught in regretting the past or worrying so much about the future. Live the life you have. Take really good care of yourself and do things that make you feel good. Now!
Posts.Title: Guilt Renae64 K-Lo

Posts.Content: Oct 1, 2014 12:45PM Jill49 wrote: Judy - welcome to a place of loving support.  I'm sorry you have to be here, but this is a group of wonderful people who will be here for you. Leah and Wilsie - I also found out (today) that I have developed 2 lesions on my liver after 6 rounds of Abraxane. Bones and lungs are stable, but liver mets are new. Crap!!!@!  I am shocked, disappointed, and scared. After 6 years with mets, I suppose it was just a matter of time and I am somewhat heartened to read about those of you who have been living with liver mets for years now.  I'll have a good long cry tonight and then get on with living. My onc wants me to start AC tomorrow. Another thing I'm scared about. So far I've done ok on all the drugs I've taken, including Abraxane, so I hope this one is tolerable.  Wishing all of you, us, good days, many more years, and lots of smiles along the way.  Thank you all for being here and reaching out.

Posts.Content: Feb 21, 2013 11:41AM Jill49 wrote: YamaMama - such a heavy burden to bear and such wise words.  Sh*t happens to every kind of person - that's life.  We don't know what will happen, but we do have a choice to live in the present and choose joy whether we have a disease or not.  This takes practice, isn't easy, and has to give space to the negative emotions with kindness towards ourselves. bravo! Waking up in the morning is no small thing - it's the small things that turn out to be the most meaningful, don't you think. I still have a body, broken and battered a bit, and still have breath. That is no small thing.  I have a warm place to live, an abundance of food, wonderful family, a new grandaughter.  One day, one step at a time. Wishing you all the best and many more years.

This disease sucks and I will likely die from it, but I still have a life to live, dancing with the knife at my throat, and have many joyful moments to experience. I choose to be positive, hard as it is sometimes.  I don't know how much time I have, but I won't as sonnyB said live it feeling angry or worried all the time. Find help to support you through this most difficult time. Wishing you peace.

Posts.Title: I'm Shrinking!! Alli_FLA Iwillwinthisbattle

Posts.Content: Dec 29, 2013 02:50PM Jill49 wrote: What a great post. When I think about the past there are many choices I made that could have been different ones.  Who knows how life would have unfolded if I had taken other paths, for better or worse.  The person I am is the result of where I've been, what I've done, what I've learned (or not learned). I don't spend a lot of time regretting paths not taken, these are merely thoughts now.  I try to stay in the present and do the best I can - appreciate the inexpressible beauty in this world, my family, the few really good friends I have had for a long time, the spiritual teachings I have received from precious teachers.  In any moment, I aim to be fully present with an open heart. Brendatrue - I have also thought a lot about the difference between guilt and regret.  Guilt seems to be a sticky burden of harsh judgement towards oneself, a trap that is really hard to free oneself from.  There are actions I regret having taken, but rather than beat myself up, I, like you, try to use the awareness to make wiser choices in the present. I doubt that when the time comes for the lights to go out for me, I will be consumed with regrets about not having chosen a career over staying home with my children, or the mistake that was my first marriage, or the house we didn't buy.  Well, maybe I will have a small moment for the gorgeous shoes I could have worn if my feet weren't hurting so much on Xeloda.

Posts.Content: Oct 3, 2014 08:07PM Jill49 wrote: Well, my first AC treatment was quite an event. In the end I only got the C. They started the IV after a couple of failures, finally got good blood return, but the veins halfway up my arm turned red and itchy. They stopped the push.  Onc ordered benadryl and zantac to stop the itch and quickly clear up the reaction.  Tried my other arm, which is on the side of my 1996 surgery.  Even though the veins were good, not having been used in 18 years, and the C flowed in well, they couldn't see any blood return. Decided to withhold  the A because of the potential tissue damage if it leaked out of the vein. The hospital nurse educator and the rest of the chemo nurses gathered around me to look at the spider web of red veins traveling up my arm and asked permission to take a picture for the nurses. So, in the end I got one of the two drugs and will finally get a port. My veins are not happy with all the poking they've had in the past 6 years.  After 5 tries and 5 hours yesterday, I'm ready.  It wasn't a terrible time - wonderful nurses, lots of warm blankets, my kindle.  Disappointing that I couldn't start the whole treatment, but at least I got something. love to all and many thanks for your support.  Jill

Posts.Content: Nov 7, 2013 01:20AM Jill49 wrote: Thanks for the laughs, ladies. I also find humor so important - it helps me stay afloat when I start to sink. I am careful with my husband and sons - they can't quite find the humor in this. I often respond to friends who ask how I am with "well, I woke up this morning, so it's a good day". I have occasionally made my onc a bit uncomfortable with my jokes about dying. I can tell he wants to laugh, and he gets as far as a smile, but is squirming a bit about laughing with a cancer patient. Surly, I love your excuse for not flossing and how great that your hygienist could share a laugh with you. And Butterfly, I'm with you. I'd rather die laughing than crying.

Posts.Content: Mar 28, 2014 12:42PM Jill49 wrote: Jill - Thanks for sharing the beautiful conversation and the pics of you and your adorable grandson (what a radiant smile he has).  Isn't grandparenthood the best?!  I have one who is a month away from 2 and another on the way.  Enjoy every moment with him.  I am hoping that I am around long enough before my final forever sleep that my grandaughter holds a vivid enough memory of me and knows that my love for her is forever.
Posts.Title: Grandchild Story JillThut april485

Posts.Content: Mar 14, 2013 11:22AM Jill49 wrote: I understand - so many things can trigger that feeling. My last birthday (coming soon), my last Thanksgiving with my family, my last trip, my last election, and on and on. For me, that kind of thinking is a place I don't want to dwell.  The feelings/thoughts arise, but they also float away. Now is now, and I am alive, breathing, and determined to live the life I have in the best way possible. I like what Glenna said about celebrating a birthday everyday. Happy Birthday everyone!

Posts.Content: Oct 25, 2013 01:09PM Jill49 wrote: Welcome to the club you'd rather not be a member of. We're sorry you have to join us, but there's no better place to be for understanding and support. We are here for you whether you are feeling hopeful, scared, angry, frustrated, happy, sad, etc.
Posts.Title: New Here Freedomchild82 AmyJM

Posts.Content: Jan 25, 2013 09:19AM Jill49 wrote: I've been on Xeloda for over 2 years straight and it's kept me stable! The only SE I have is hand/foot syndome.  My feel were peeling a lot, but I've been using creams with high urea content and the peeling is minimal now.  My feet do get quite red at times and burn, but it comes and goes. I have deep grooves aroung my heels and between my big toe and the ball of my foot - where the toe bends.  I should probably use the cream several times a day. My hands get quite dry and peel a bit - I use lotion many times a day to keep them moist. A tiny bit of numbness on my fingertips.  Occasionally I take a break - either a whol cyle or an extra week off. It helps with the healing. All in all, it's been good to me and the SEs are a relatively small price to pay for STABLE!

Posts.Content: Jan 9, 2013 05:32AM Jill49 wrote: I had a bone biopsy on the mastoid bone behind my ear.  It was not nearly as big a deal as finding that cancer had returned after 11 years.  This is a challenging and adjustment to make for the newly diagnosed, but know that bone mets alone can often be managed for a long time. Wishing you many, many years. Shed the tears, be kind to yourself, and get on with living your life.
